case_vignette: A 21-YEAR-OLD MAN COMES TO THE PHYSICIAN BECAUSE OF PRURITUS AND A HYPOPIGMENTED RASH ON HIS UPPER BODY FOR 5 DAYS. HE FIRST NOTICED THE SYMPTOMS AFTER RETURNING FROM A BUSINESS TRIP LAST WEEK IN THE BAHAMAS. WHILE HE WAS THERE, HE VISITED A COUPLE OF BEACHES AND WENT HIKING WITH SOME COWORKERS. THE RASH INITIALLY STARTED AS A SINGLE LESION ON HIS UPPER BACK BUT SINCE THEN HAS EXTENDED TO HIS SHOULDERS. HE HAS A HISTORY OF TYPE 1 DIABETES MELLITUS CONTROLLED WITH AN INSULIN PUMP. HE WORKS AS AN OFFICE MANAGER AND HAS NO KNOWN EXPOSURE TO MELANOCYTOTOXIC CHEMICALS. HE HAS BEEN SEXUALLY ACTIVE WITH THREE FEMALE PARTNERS OVER THE PAST YEAR AND USES CONDOMS INCONSISTENTLY. HE IS 183 CM (6 FT) TALL AND WEIGHS 80 KG (176 LB); BMI IS 23.9 KG/M2. HIS TEMPERATURE IS 37.2°C (99°F), PULSE IS 78/MIN, AND BLOOD PRESSURE IS 130/84 MM HG. A PHOTOGRAPH OF THE RASH IS SHOWN. ONE MONTH AGO, HIS HEMOGLOBIN A1C WAS 7.8%.
question: WHICH OF THE FOLLOWING IS MOST LIKELY TO CONFIRM THE DIAGNOSIS?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Dermatology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask only one question at a time, and it should not be more than 1 line. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. Do not ask the same question multiple times. Ask different questions to cover more information. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain, only give the diagnosis name. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized. You must give only 1 diagnosis otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
Hello! I am experiencing itching and a lighter-colored rash on my upper body.
Have you noticed any changes in the texture of your skin where the rash is present?
Yes, the rash initially started as a single spot on my upper back before spreading to my shoulders.
Have you been exposed to any new products, plants, or environments that could have caused an allergic reaction?
Yes, I recently returned from a trip to the Bahamas where I visited beaches and went hiking.
Do you have any medical history of skin conditions or allergies?
I have a history of type 1 diabetes mellitus, but no known history of skin conditions or allergies.
Has anyone in your family had similar skin issues or other dermatological conditions?
I am not aware of any family history of similar skin issues or other dermatological conditions.
Final Diagnosis: Tinea Versicolor
